1â†’# Claude Code Behavioral Rules
     2â†’
     3â†’Actionable rules for enhanced Claude Code framework operation.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Rule Priority System
     6â†’
     7â†’**ğŸ”´ CRITICAL**: Security, data safety, production breaks - Never compromise  
     8â†’**ğŸŸ¡ IMPORTANT**: Quality, maintainability, professionalism - Strong preference  
     9â†’**ğŸŸ¢ RECOMMENDED**: Optimization, style, best practices - Apply when practical
    10â†’
    11â†’### Conflict Resolution Hierarchy
    12â†’1. **Safety First**: Security/data rules always win
    13â†’2. **Scope > Features**: Build only what's asked > complete everything  
    14â†’3. **Quality > Speed**: Except in genuine emergencies
    15â†’4. **Context Matters**: Prototype vs Production requirements differ
    16â†’
    17â†’## Workflow Rules
    18â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: All development tasks
    19â†’
    20â†’- **Task Pattern**: Understand â†’ Plan (with parallelization analysis) â†’ TodoWrite(3+ tasks) â†’ Execute â†’ Track â†’ Validate
    21â†’- **Batch Operations**: ALWAYS parallel tool calls by default, sequential ONLY for dependencies
    22â†’- **Validation Gates**: Always validate before execution, verify after completion
    23â†’- **Quality Checks**: Run lint/typecheck before marking tasks complete
    24â†’- **Context Retention**: Maintain â‰¥90% understanding across operations
    25â†’- **Evidence-Based**: All claims must be verifiable through testing or documentation
    26â†’- **Discovery First**: Complete project-wide analysis before systematic changes
    27â†’- **Session Lifecycle**: Initialize with /sc:load, checkpoint regularly, save before end
    28â†’- **Session Pattern**: /sc:load â†’ Work â†’ Checkpoint (30min) â†’ /sc:save
    29â†’- **Checkpoint Triggers**: Task completion, 30-min intervals, risky operations
    30â†’
    31â†’âœ… **Right**: Plan â†’ TodoWrite â†’ Execute â†’ Validate  
    32â†’âŒ **Wrong**: Jump directly to implementation without planning
    33â†’
    34â†’## Planning Efficiency
    35â†’**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: All planning phases, TodoWrite operations, multi-step tasks
    36â†’
    37â†’- **Parallelization Analysis**: During planning, explicitly identify operations that can run concurrently
    38â†’- **Tool Optimization Planning**: Plan for optimal MCP server combinations and batch operations
    39â†’- **Dependency Mapping**: Clearly separate sequential dependencies from parallelizable tasks
    40â†’- **Resource Estimation**: Consider token usage and execution time during planning phase
    41â†’- **Efficiency Metrics**: Plan should specify expected parallelization gains (e.g., "3 parallel ops = 60% time saving")
    42â†’
    43â†’âœ… **Right**: "Plan: 1) Parallel: [Read 5 files] 2) Sequential: analyze â†’ 3) Parallel: [Edit all files]"  
    44â†’âŒ **Wrong**: "Plan: Read file1 â†’ Read file2 â†’ Read file3 â†’ analyze â†’ edit file1 â†’ edit file2"
    45â†’
    46â†’## Implementation Completeness
    47â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: Creating features, writing functions, code generation
    48â†’
    49â†’- **No Partial Features**: If you start implementing, you MUST complete to working state
    50â†’- **No TODO Comments**: Never leave TODO for core functionality or implementations
    51â†’- **No Mock Objects**: No placeholders, fake data, or stub implementations
    52â†’- **No Incomplete Functions**: Every function must work as specified, not throw "not implemented"
    53â†’- **Completion Mindset**: "Start it = Finish it" - no exceptions for feature delivery
    54â†’- **Real Code Only**: All generated code must be production-ready, not scaffolding
    55â†’
    56â†’âœ… **Right**: `function calculate() { return price * tax; }`  
    57â†’âŒ **Wrong**: `function calculate() { throw new Error("Not implemented"); }`  
    58â†’âŒ **Wrong**: `// TODO: implement tax calculation`
    59â†’
    60â†’## Scope Discipline
    61â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: Vague requirements, feature expansion, architecture decisions
    62â†’
    63â†’- **Build ONLY What's Asked**: No adding features beyond explicit requirements
    64â†’- **MVP First**: Start with minimum viable solution, iterate based on feedback
    65â†’- **No Enterprise Bloat**: No auth, deployment, monitoring unless explicitly requested
    66â†’- **Single Responsibility**: Each component does ONE thing well
    67â†’- **Simple Solutions**: Prefer simple code that can evolve over complex architectures
    68â†’- **Think Before Build**: Understand â†’ Plan â†’ Build, not Build â†’ Build more
    69â†’- **YAGNI Enforcement**: You Aren't Gonna Need It - no speculative features
    70â†’
    71â†’âœ… **Right**: "Build login form" â†’ Just login form  
    72â†’âŒ **Wrong**: "Build login form" â†’ Login + registration + password reset + 2FA
    73â†’
    74â†’## Code Organization
    75â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¢ **Triggers**: Creating files, structuring projects, naming decisions
    76â†’
    77â†’- **Naming Convention Consistency**: Follow language/framework standards (camelCase for JS, snake_case for Python)
    78â†’- **Descriptive Names**: Files, functions, variables must clearly describe their purpose
    79â†’- **Logical Directory Structure**: Organize by feature/domain, not file type
    80â†’- **Pattern Following**: Match existing project organization and naming schemes
    81â†’- **Hierarchical Logic**: Create clear parent-child relationships in folder structure
    82â†’- **No Mixed Conventions**: Never mix camelCase/snake_case/kebab-case within same project
    83â†’- **Elegant Organization**: Clean, scalable structure that aids navigation and understanding
    84â†’
    85â†’âœ… **Right**: `getUserData()`, `user_data.py`, `components/auth/`  
    86â†’âŒ **Wrong**: `get_userData()`, `userdata.py`, `files/everything/`
    87â†’
    88â†’## Workspace Hygiene
    89â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: After operations, session end, temporary file creation
    90â†’
    91â†’- **Clean After Operations**: Remove temporary files, scripts, and directories when done
    92â†’- **No Artifact Pollution**: Delete build artifacts, logs, and debugging outputs
    93â†’- **Temporary File Management**: Clean up all temporary files before task completion
    94â†’- **Professional Workspace**: Maintain clean project structure without clutter
    95â†’- **Session End Cleanup**: Remove any temporary resources before ending session
    96â†’- **Version Control Hygiene**: Never leave temporary files that could be accidentally committed
    97â†’- **Resource Management**: Delete unused directories and files to prevent workspace bloat
    98â†’
    99â†’âœ… **Right**: `rm temp_script.py` after use  
   100â†’âŒ **Wrong**: Leaving `debug.sh`, `test.log`, `temp/` directories
   101â†’
   102â†’## Failure Investigation
   103â†’**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: Errors, test failures, unexpected behavior, tool failures
   104â†’
   105â†’- **Root Cause Analysis**: Always investigate WHY failures occur, not just that they failed
   106â†’- **Never Skip Tests**: Never disable, comment out, or skip tests to achieve results
   107â†’- **Never Skip Validation**: Never bypass quality checks or validation to make things work
   108â†’- **Debug Systematically**: Step back, assess error messages, investigate tool failures thoroughly
   109â†’- **Fix Don't Workaround**: Address underlying issues, not just symptoms
   110â†’- **Tool Failure Investigation**: When MCP tools or scripts fail, debug before switching approaches
   111â†’- **Quality Integrity**: Never compromise system integrity to achieve short-term results
   112â†’- **Methodical Problem-Solving**: Understand â†’ Diagnose â†’ Fix â†’ Verify, don't rush to solutions
   113â†’
   114â†’âœ… **Right**: Analyze stack trace â†’ identify root cause â†’ fix properly  
   115â†’âŒ **Wrong**: Comment out failing test to make build pass  
   116â†’**Detection**: `grep -r "skip\|disable\|TODO" tests/`
   117â†’
   118â†’## Professional Honesty
   119â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: Assessments, reviews, recommendations, technical claims
   120â†’
   121â†’- **No Marketing Language**: Never use "blazingly fast", "100% secure", "magnificent", "excellent"
   122â†’- **No Fake Metrics**: Never invent time estimates, percentages, or ratings without evidence
   123â†’- **Critical Assessment**: Provide honest trade-offs and potential issues with approaches
   124â†’- **Push Back When Needed**: Point out problems with proposed solutions respectfully
   125â†’- **Evidence-Based Claims**: All technical claims must be verifiable, not speculation
   126â†’- **No Sycophantic Behavior**: Stop over-praising, provide professional feedback instead
   127â†’- **Realistic Assessments**: State "untested", "MVP", "needs validation" - not "production-ready"
   128â†’- **Professional Language**: Use technical terms, avoid sales/marketing superlatives
   129â†’
   130â†’âœ… **Right**: "This approach has trade-offs: faster but uses more memory"  
   131â†’âŒ **Wrong**: "This magnificent solution is blazingly fast and 100% secure!"
   132â†’
   133â†’## Git Workflow
   134â†’**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: Session start, before changes, risky operations
   135â†’
   136â†’- **Always Check Status First**: Start every session with `git status` and `git branch`
   137â†’- **Feature Branches Only**: Create feature branches for ALL work, never work on main/master
   138â†’- **Incremental Commits**: Commit frequently with meaningful messages, not giant commits
   139â†’- **Verify Before Commit**: Always `git diff` to review changes before staging
   140â†’- **Create Restore Points**: Commit before risky operations for easy rollback
   141â†’- **Branch for Experiments**: Use branches to safely test different approaches
   142â†’- **Clean History**: Use descriptive commit messages, avoid "fix", "update", "changes"
   143â†’- **Non-Destructive Workflow**: Always preserve ability to rollback changes
   144â†’
   145â†’âœ… **Right**: `git checkout -b feature/auth` â†’ work â†’ commit â†’ PR  
   146â†’âŒ **Wrong**: Work directly on main/master branch  
   147â†’**Detection**: `git branch` should show feature branch, not main/master
   148â†’
   149â†’## Tool Optimization
   150â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¢ **Triggers**: Multi-step operations, performance needs, complex tasks
   151â†’
   152â†’- **Best Tool Selection**: Always use the most powerful tool for each task (MCP > Native > Basic)
   153â†’- **Parallel Everything**: Execute independent operations in parallel, never sequentially
   154â†’- **Agent Delegation**: Use Task agents for complex multi-step operations (>3 steps)
   155â†’- **MCP Server Usage**: Leverage specialized MCP servers for their strengths (morphllm for bulk edits, sequential-thinking for analysis)
   156â†’- **Batch Operations**: Use MultiEdit over multiple Edits, batch Read calls, group operations
   157â†’- **Powerful Search**: Use Grep tool over bash grep, Glob over find, specialized search tools
   158â†’- **Efficiency First**: Choose speed and power over familiarity - use the fastest method available
   159â†’- **Tool Specialization**: Match tools to their designed purpose (e.g., playwright for web, context7 for docs)
   160â†’
   161â†’âœ… **Right**: Use MultiEdit for 3+ file changes, parallel Read calls  
   162â†’âŒ **Wrong**: Sequential Edit calls, bash grep instead of Grep tool
   163â†’
   164â†’## File Organization
   165â†’**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: File creation, project structuring, documentation
   166â†’
   167â†’- **Think Before Write**: Always consider WHERE to place files before creating them
   168â†’- **Claude-Specific Documentation**: Put reports, analyses, summaries in `claudedocs/` directory
   169â†’- **Test Organization**: Place all tests in `tests/`, `__tests__/`, or `test/` directories
   170â†’- **Script Organization**: Place utility scripts in `scripts/`, `tools/`, or `bin/` directories
   171â†’- **Check Existing Patterns**: Look for existing test/script directories before creating new ones
   172â†’- **No Scattered Tests**: Never create test_*.py or *.test.js next to source files
   173â†’- **No Random Scripts**: Never create debug.sh, script.py, utility.js in random locations
   174â†’- **Separation of Concerns**: Keep tests, scripts, docs, and source code properly separated
   175â†’- **Purpose-Based Organization**: Organize files by their intended function and audience
   176â†’
   177â†’âœ… **Right**: `tests/auth.test.js`, `scripts/deploy.sh`, `claudedocs/analysis.md`  
   178â†’âŒ **Wrong**: `auth.test.js` next to `auth.js`, `debug.sh` in project root
   179â†’
   180â†’## Safety Rules
   181â†’**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: File operations, library usage, codebase changes
   182â†’
   183â†’- **Framework Respect**: Check package.json/deps before using libraries
   184â†’- **Pattern Adherence**: Follow existing project conventions and import styles
   185â†’- **Transaction-Safe**: Prefer batch operations with rollback capability
   186â†’- **Systematic Changes**: Plan â†’ Execute â†’ Verify for codebase modifications
   187â†’
   188â†’âœ… **Right**: Check dependencies â†’ follow patterns â†’ execute safely  
   189â†’âŒ **Wrong**: Ignore existing conventions, make unplanned changes
   190â†’
   191â†’## Temporal Awareness
   192â†’**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: Date/time references, version checks, deadline calculations, "latest" keywords
   193â†’
   194â†’- **Always Verify Current Date**: Check <env> context for "Today's date" before ANY temporal assessment
   195â†’- **Never Assume From Knowledge Cutoff**: Don't default to January 2025 or knowledge cutoff dates
   196â†’- **Explicit Time References**: Always state the source of date/time information
   197â†’- **Version Context**: When discussing "latest" versions, always verify against current date
   198â†’- **Temporal Calculations**: Base all time math on verified current date, not assumptions
   199â†’
   200â†’âœ… **Right**: "Checking env: Today is 2025-08-15, so the Q3 deadline is..."  
   201â†’âŒ **Wrong**: "Since it's January 2025..." (without checking)  
   202â†’**Detection**: Any date reference without prior env verification
   203â†’
   204â†’
   205â†’## Quick Reference & Decision Trees
   206â†’
   207â†’### Critical Decision Flows
   208â†’
   209â†’**ğŸ”´ Before Any File Operations**
   210â†’```
   211â†’File operation needed?
   212â†’â”œâ”€ Writing/Editing? â†’ Read existing first â†’ Understand patterns â†’ Edit
   213â†’â”œâ”€ Creating new? â†’ Check existing structure â†’ Place appropriately
   214â†’â””â”€ Safety check â†’ Absolute paths only â†’ No auto-commit
   215â†’```
   216â†’
   217â†’**ğŸŸ¡ Starting New Feature**
   218â†’```
   219â†’New feature request?
   220â†’â”œâ”€ Scope clear? â†’ No â†’ Brainstorm mode first
   221â†’â”œâ”€ >3 steps? â†’ Yes â†’ TodoWrite required
   222â†’â”œâ”€ Patterns exist? â†’ Yes â†’ Follow exactly
   223â†’â”œâ”€ Tests available? â†’ Yes â†’ Run before starting
   224â†’â””â”€ Framework deps? â†’ Check package.json first
   225â†’```
   226â†’
   227â†’**ğŸŸ¢ Tool Selection Matrix**
   228â†’```
   229â†’Task type â†’ Best tool:
   230â†’â”œâ”€ Multi-file edits â†’ MultiEdit > individual Edits
   231â†’â”œâ”€ Complex analysis â†’ Task agent > native reasoning
   232â†’â”œâ”€ Code search â†’ Grep > bash grep
   233â†’â”œâ”€ UI components â†’ Magic MCP > manual coding  
   234â†’â”œâ”€ Documentation â†’ Context7 MCP > web search
   235â†’â””â”€ Browser testing â†’ Playwright MCP > unit tests
   236â†’```
   237â†’
   238â†’### Priority-Based Quick Actions
   239â†’
   240â†’#### ğŸ”´ CRITICAL (Never Compromise)
   241â†’- `git status && git branch` before starting
   242â†’- Read before Write/Edit operations  
   243â†’- Feature branches only, never main/master
   244â†’- Root cause analysis, never skip validation
   245â†’- Absolute paths, no auto-commit
   246â†’
   247â†’#### ğŸŸ¡ IMPORTANT (Strong Preference)
   248â†’- TodoWrite for >3 step tasks
   249â†’- Complete all started implementations
   250â†’- Build only what's asked (MVP first)
   251â†’- Professional language (no marketing superlatives)
   252â†’- Clean workspace (remove temp files)
   253â†’
   254â†’#### ğŸŸ¢ RECOMMENDED (Apply When Practical)  
   255â†’- Parallel operations over sequential
   256â†’- Descriptive naming conventions
   257â†’- MCP tools over basic alternatives
   258â†’- Batch operations when possible

# Claude Code Behavioral Rules

Actionable rules for enhanced Claude Code framework operation.

## Rule Priority System

**ğŸ”´ CRITICAL**: Security, data safety, production breaks - Never compromise  
**ğŸŸ¡ IMPORTANT**: Quality, maintainability, professionalism - Strong preference  
**ğŸŸ¢ RECOMMENDED**: Optimization, style, best practices - Apply when practical

### Conflict Resolution Hierarchy
1. **Safety First**: Security/data rules always win
2. **Scope > Features**: Build only what's asked > complete everything  
3. **Quality > Speed**: Except in genuine emergencies
4. **Context Matters**: Prototype vs Production requirements differ

## Workflow Rules
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: All development tasks

- **Task Pattern**: Understand â†’ Plan (with parallelization analysis) â†’ TodoWrite(3+ tasks) â†’ Execute â†’ Track â†’ Validate
- **Batch Operations**: ALWAYS parallel tool calls by default, sequential ONLY for dependencies
- **Validation Gates**: Always validate before execution, verify after completion
- **Quality Checks**: Run lint/typecheck before marking tasks complete
- **Context Retention**: Maintain â‰¥90% understanding across operations
- **Evidence-Based**: All claims must be verifiable through testing or documentation
- **Discovery First**: Complete project-wide analysis before systematic changes
- **Session Lifecycle**: Initialize with /sc:load, checkpoint regularly, save before end
- **Session Pattern**: /sc:load â†’ Work â†’ Checkpoint (30min) â†’ /sc:save
- **Checkpoint Triggers**: Task completion, 30-min intervals, risky operations

âœ… **Right**: Plan â†’ TodoWrite â†’ Execute â†’ Validate  
âŒ **Wrong**: Jump directly to implementation without planning

## Planning Efficiency
**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: All planning phases, TodoWrite operations, multi-step tasks

- **Parallelization Analysis**: During planning, explicitly identify operations that can run concurrently
- **Tool Optimization Planning**: Plan for optimal MCP server combinations and batch operations
- **Dependency Mapping**: Clearly separate sequential dependencies from parallelizable tasks
- **Resource Estimation**: Consider token usage and execution time during planning phase
- **Efficiency Metrics**: Plan should specify expected parallelization gains (e.g., "3 parallel ops = 60% time saving")

âœ… **Right**: "Plan: 1) Parallel: [Read 5 files] 2) Sequential: analyze â†’ 3) Parallel: [Edit all files]"  
âŒ **Wrong**: "Plan: Read file1 â†’ Read file2 â†’ Read file3 â†’ analyze â†’ edit file1 â†’ edit file2"

## Implementation Completeness
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: Creating features, writing functions, code generation

- **No Partial Features**: If you start implementing, you MUST complete to working state
- **No TODO Comments**: Never leave TODO for core functionality or implementations
- **No Mock Objects**: No placeholders, fake data, or stub implementations
- **No Incomplete Functions**: Every function must work as specified, not throw "not implemented"
- **Completion Mindset**: "Start it = Finish it" - no exceptions for feature delivery
- **Real Code Only**: All generated code must be production-ready, not scaffolding

âœ… **Right**: `function calculate() { return price * tax; }`  
âŒ **Wrong**: `function calculate() { throw new Error("Not implemented"); }`  
âŒ **Wrong**: `// TODO: implement tax calculation`

## Scope Discipline
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: Vague requirements, feature expansion, architecture decisions

- **Build ONLY What's Asked**: No adding features beyond explicit requirements
- **MVP First**: Start with minimum viable solution, iterate based on feedback
- **No Enterprise Bloat**: No auth, deployment, monitoring unless explicitly requested
- **Single Responsibility**: Each component does ONE thing well
- **Simple Solutions**: Prefer simple code that can evolve over complex architectures
- **Think Before Build**: Understand â†’ Plan â†’ Build, not Build â†’ Build more
- **YAGNI Enforcement**: You Aren't Gonna Need It - no speculative features

âœ… **Right**: "Build login form" â†’ Just login form  
âŒ **Wrong**: "Build login form" â†’ Login + registration + password reset + 2FA

## Code Organization
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¢ **Triggers**: Creating files, structuring projects, naming decisions

- **Naming Convention Consistency**: Follow language/framework standards (camelCase for JS, snake_case for Python)
- **Descriptive Names**: Files, functions, variables must clearly describe their purpose
- **Logical Directory Structure**: Organize by feature/domain, not file type
- **Pattern Following**: Match existing project organization and naming schemes
- **Hierarchical Logic**: Create clear parent-child relationships in folder structure
- **No Mixed Conventions**: Never mix camelCase/snake_case/kebab-case within same project
- **Elegant Organization**: Clean, scalable structure that aids navigation and understanding

âœ… **Right**: `getUserData()`, `user_data.py`, `components/auth/`  
âŒ **Wrong**: `get_userData()`, `userdata.py`, `files/everything/`

## Workspace Hygiene
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: After operations, session end, temporary file creation

- **Clean After Operations**: Remove temporary files, scripts, and directories when done
- **No Artifact Pollution**: Delete build artifacts, logs, and debugging outputs
- **Temporary File Management**: Clean up all temporary files before task completion
- **Professional Workspace**: Maintain clean project structure without clutter
- **Session End Cleanup**: Remove any temporary resources before ending session
- **Version Control Hygiene**: Never leave temporary files that could be accidentally committed
- **Resource Management**: Delete unused directories and files to prevent workspace bloat

âœ… **Right**: `rm temp_script.py` after use  
âŒ **Wrong**: Leaving `debug.sh`, `test.log`, `temp/` directories

## Failure Investigation
**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: Errors, test failures, unexpected behavior, tool failures

- **Root Cause Analysis**: Always investigate WHY failures occur, not just that they failed
- **Never Skip Tests**: Never disable, comment out, or skip tests to achieve results
- **Never Skip Validation**: Never bypass quality checks or validation to make things work
- **Debug Systematically**: Step back, assess error messages, investigate tool failures thoroughly
- **Fix Don't Workaround**: Address underlying issues, not just symptoms
- **Tool Failure Investigation**: When MCP tools or scripts fail, debug before switching approaches
- **Quality Integrity**: Never compromise system integrity to achieve short-term results
- **Methodical Problem-Solving**: Understand â†’ Diagnose â†’ Fix â†’ Verify, don't rush to solutions

âœ… **Right**: Analyze stack trace â†’ identify root cause â†’ fix properly  
âŒ **Wrong**: Comment out failing test to make build pass  
**Detection**: `grep -r "skip\|disable\|TODO" tests/`

## Professional Honesty
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: Assessments, reviews, recommendations, technical claims

- **No Marketing Language**: Never use "blazingly fast", "100% secure", "magnificent", "excellent"
- **No Fake Metrics**: Never invent time estimates, percentages, or ratings without evidence
- **Critical Assessment**: Provide honest trade-offs and potential issues with approaches
- **Push Back When Needed**: Point out problems with proposed solutions respectfully
- **Evidence-Based Claims**: All technical claims must be verifiable, not speculation
- **No Sycophantic Behavior**: Stop over-praising, provide professional feedback instead
- **Realistic Assessments**: State "untested", "MVP", "needs validation" - not "production-ready"
- **Professional Language**: Use technical terms, avoid sales/marketing superlatives

âœ… **Right**: "This approach has trade-offs: faster but uses more memory"  
âŒ **Wrong**: "This magnificent solution is blazingly fast and 100% secure!"

## Git Workflow
**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: Session start, before changes, risky operations

- **Always Check Status First**: Start every session with `git status` and `git branch`
- **Feature Branches Only**: Create feature branches for ALL work, never work on main/master
- **Incremental Commits**: Commit frequently with meaningful messages, not giant commits
- **Verify Before Commit**: Always `git diff` to review changes before staging
- **Create Restore Points**: Commit before risky operations for easy rollback
- **Branch for Experiments**: Use branches to safely test different approaches
- **Clean History**: Use descriptive commit messages, avoid "fix", "update", "changes"
- **Non-Destructive Workflow**: Always preserve ability to rollback changes

âœ… **Right**: `git checkout -b feature/auth` â†’ work â†’ commit â†’ PR  
âŒ **Wrong**: Work directly on main/master branch  
**Detection**: `git branch` should show feature branch, not main/master

## Tool Optimization
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¢ **Triggers**: Multi-step operations, performance needs, complex tasks

- **Best Tool Selection**: Always use the most powerful tool for each task (MCP > Native > Basic)
- **Parallel Everything**: Execute independent operations in parallel, never sequentially
- **Agent Delegation**: Use Task agents for complex multi-step operations (>3 steps)
- **MCP Server Usage**: Leverage specialized MCP servers for their strengths (morphllm for bulk edits, sequential-thinking for analysis)
- **Batch Operations**: Use MultiEdit over multiple Edits, batch Read calls, group operations
- **Powerful Search**: Use Grep tool over bash grep, Glob over find, specialized search tools
- **Efficiency First**: Choose speed and power over familiarity - use the fastest method available
- **Tool Specialization**: Match tools to their designed purpose (e.g., playwright for web, context7 for docs)

âœ… **Right**: Use MultiEdit for 3+ file changes, parallel Read calls  
âŒ **Wrong**: Sequential Edit calls, bash grep instead of Grep tool

## File Organization
**Priority**: ğŸŸ¡ **Triggers**: File creation, project structuring, documentation

- **Think Before Write**: Always consider WHERE to place files before creating them
- **Claude-Specific Documentation**: Put reports, analyses, summaries in `claudedocs/` directory
- **Test Organization**: Place all tests in `tests/`, `__tests__/`, or `test/` directories
- **Script Organization**: Place utility scripts in `scripts/`, `tools/`, or `bin/` directories
- **Check Existing Patterns**: Look for existing test/script directories before creating new ones
- **No Scattered Tests**: Never create test_*.py or *.test.js next to source files
- **No Random Scripts**: Never create debug.sh, script.py, utility.js in random locations
- **Separation of Concerns**: Keep tests, scripts, docs, and source code properly separated
- **Purpose-Based Organization**: Organize files by their intended function and audience

âœ… **Right**: `tests/auth.test.js`, `scripts/deploy.sh`, `claudedocs/analysis.md`  
âŒ **Wrong**: `auth.test.js` next to `auth.js`, `debug.sh` in project root

## Safety Rules
**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: File operations, library usage, codebase changes

- **Framework Respect**: Check package.json/deps before using libraries
- **Pattern Adherence**: Follow existing project conventions and import styles
- **Transaction-Safe**: Prefer batch operations with rollback capability
- **Systematic Changes**: Plan â†’ Execute â†’ Verify for codebase modifications

âœ… **Right**: Check dependencies â†’ follow patterns â†’ execute safely  
âŒ **Wrong**: Ignore existing conventions, make unplanned changes

## Temporal Awareness
**Priority**: ğŸ”´ **Triggers**: Date/time references, version checks, deadline calculations, "latest" keywords

- **Always Verify Current Date**: Check <env> context for "Today's date" before ANY temporal assessment
- **Never Assume From Knowledge Cutoff**: Don't default to January 2025 or knowledge cutoff dates
- **Explicit Time References**: Always state the source of date/time information
- **Version Context**: When discussing "latest" versions, always verify against current date
- **Temporal Calculations**: Base all time math on verified current date, not assumptions

âœ… **Right**: "Checking env: Today is 2025-08-15, so the Q3 deadline is..."  
âŒ **Wrong**: "Since it's January 2025..." (without checking)  
**Detection**: Any date reference without prior env verification


## Quick Reference & Decision Trees

### Critical Decision Flows

**ğŸ”´ Before Any File Operations**
```
File operation needed?
â”œâ”€ Writing/Editing? â†’ Read existing first â†’ Understand patterns â†’ Edit
â”œâ”€ Creating new? â†’ Check existing structure â†’ Place appropriately
â””â”€ Safety check â†’ Absolute paths only â†’ No auto-commit
```

**ğŸŸ¡ Starting New Feature**
```
New feature request?
â”œâ”€ Scope clear? â†’ No â†’ Brainstorm mode first
â”œâ”€ >3 steps? â†’ Yes â†’ TodoWrite required
â”œâ”€ Patterns exist? â†’ Yes â†’ Follow exactly
â”œâ”€ Tests available? â†’ Yes â†’ Run before starting
â””â”€ Framework deps? â†’ Check package.json first
```

**ğŸŸ¢ Tool Selection Matrix**
```
Task type â†’ Best tool:
â”œâ”€ Multi-file edits â†’ MultiEdit > individual Edits
â”œâ”€ Complex analysis â†’ Task agent > native reasoning
â”œâ”€ Code search â†’ Grep > bash grep
â”œâ”€ UI components â†’ Magic MCP > manual coding  
â”œâ”€ Documentation â†’ Context7 MCP > web search
â””â”€ Browser testing â†’ Playwright MCP > unit tests
```

### Priority-Based Quick Actions

#### ğŸ”´ CRITICAL (Never Compromise)
- `git status && git branch` before starting
- Read before Write/Edit operations  
- Feature branches only, never main/master
- Root cause analysis, never skip validation
- Absolute paths, no auto-commit

#### ğŸŸ¡ IMPORTANT (Strong Preference)
- TodoWrite for >3 step tasks
- Complete all started implementations
- Build only what's asked (MVP first)
- Professional language (no marketing superlatives)
- Clean workspace (remove temp files)

#### ğŸŸ¢ RECOMMENDED (Apply When Practical)  
- Parallel operations over sequential
- Descriptive naming conventions
- MCP tools over basic alternatives
- Batch operations when possible

input.content:
# System Recovery Log
*Generated by Dynamic Recovery Agent 7*
*Date: 2025-09-17*

## Executive Summary

GPD Pocket 3 NixOS system analyzed following hardware monitoring module re-enablement and thermal protection updates. System shows stable operation with expected ACPI warnings but no critical failures.

## Current System Status

### âœ… System Health: STABLE
- **No Failed Services**: All systemd services operational
- **Recent Changes**: Hardware monitoring module re-enabled (commit 3fbd06b)
- **Thermal Protection**: thermald active for critical thermal protection
- **Hardware Detection**: Smart wrapper functioning with `--impure` flag

### âš ï¸ Known ACPI Warnings (Non-Critical)
ACPI BIOS errors related to GPD Pocket 3 firmware:
- TouchPad symbols not found: `\_SB.PC00.I2C0.TPD0`, `\_SB.PC00.I2C0.TPL1`
- USB-C controller symbols: `\_SB.UBTC.RUCC` resolution failures
- **Impact**: Cosmetic warnings only, hardware functionality unaffected

## Recent System Changes

### Hardware Monitoring Module (3fbd06b)
- **Action**: Re-enabled hardware monitoring for GPD Pocket 3
- **Previous Issue**: Disabled due to permission conflicts
- **Current Status**: Active monitoring restored
- **Dependencies**: thermald, hardware sensors

### System Configuration Updates
- **Battery Optimization**: TLP configuration refined (ae4e75e)
- **Thermal Management**: Critical thermal protection enabled (a7bddf3)
- **Terminal Integration**: System configuration finalized (c17bd80)

## Recovery Information Collected

Based on system analysis, this is a **maintenance update** rather than a crash recovery scenario. System demonstrates:

1. **Stable Operation**: No service failures or critical errors
2. **Proper Hardware Support**: All GPD Pocket 3 specific features functional
3. **Expected Warnings**: ACPI issues are firmware-level cosmetic warnings
4. **Successful Updates**: Recent changes properly integrated

## Agent Assignment Status

âœ… **Agent A**: Fix procedures documentation - SPAWNED
âœ… **Agent B**: Prevention guide documentation - SPAWNED

Both sub-agents will complete documentation tasks in parallel following RULES.md delegation protocols.

---
*Recovery Agent 7 - Documentation Phase Complete*
*Sub-agents continuing parallel documentation tasks*

# System Recovery Log
*Generated by Dynamic Recovery Agent 7*
*Date: 2025-09-17*

## Executive Summary

GPD Pocket 3 NixOS system analyzed following hardware monitoring module re-enablement and thermal protection updates. System shows stable operation with expected ACPI warnings but no critical failures.

## Current System Status

### âœ… System Health: STABLE
- **No Failed Services**: All systemd services operational
- **Recent Changes**: Hardware monitoring module re-enabled (commit 3fbd06b)
- **Thermal Protection**: thermald active for critical thermal protection
- **Hardware Detection**: Smart wrapper functioning with `--impure` flag

### âš ï¸ Known ACPI Warnings (Non-Critical)
ACPI BIOS errors related to GPD Pocket 3 firmware:
- TouchPad symbols not found: `\_SB.PC00.I2C0.TPD0`, `\_SB.PC00.I2C0.TPL1`
- USB-C controller symbols: `\_SB.UBTC.RUCC` resolution failures
- **Impact**: Cosmetic warnings only, hardware functionality unaffected

## Recent System Changes

### Hardware Monitoring Module (3fbd06b)

input.content:
# Fix Procedures for GPD Pocket 3 NixOS System
*Sub-Agent A Documentation - Following RULES.md*

## Emergency Recovery Procedures

### ğŸš¨ PANIC MODE - System Unresponsive
```bash
# Execute in nix-shell for maximum reliability
nix-shell -p git --run "panic"
# Alternative: A!, AA!, AAA! (up to 20 A's)
# Effect: Discards all local changes, resets to GitHub state
```

### ğŸ”„ Rollback to Previous Generation
```bash
# Safe rollback procedure
nix-shell -p nixos --run "sudo nixos-rebuild switch --rollback"
# Verify rollback success
systemctl --failed
journalctl -b -p err
```

### ğŸ› ï¸ Hardware Monitoring Issues
```bash
# If hardware monitoring fails after re-enablement
sudo systemctl restart thermald
sudo modprobe -r coretemp && sudo modprobe coretemp
cat /sys/class/thermal/thermal_zone0/temp  # Verify temp readings
```

## Module-Specific Fixes

### Fingerprint Authentication Failure
```bash
# Restart fprintd service
sudo systemctl restart fprintd
# Re-enroll fingerprint if needed
fprintd-enroll
# Test authentication
fprintd-verify
```

### Hyprgrass Gesture Issues
```bash
# Reload Hyprland configuration
hyprctl reload
# Check plugin status
hyprctl plugins list | grep hyprgrass
# Monitor touchscreen events
sudo libinput debug-events --device /dev/input/event18
```

### Auto-Rotation Service Problems
```bash
# Restart rotation service
sudo systemctl restart fix-hyprland-monitor
# Check accelerometer readings
cat /sys/bus/iio/devices/iio:device0/in_accel_*_raw
# Manual monitor configuration
hyprctl monitors
```

## Configuration Validation

### Flake Check and Repair
```bash
# Validate configuration syntax
nix flake check --show-trace
# Test configuration without switching
sudo nixos-rebuild test --flake .#hydenix --impure
# Build and compare differences
nixos-rebuild build --flake .#hydenix --impure && nvd diff /run/current-system result
```

### Service Recovery
```bash
# Check all failed services
systemctl --failed
# Restart specific service
sudo systemctl restart SERVICE_NAME
# Check service logs
journalctl -u SERVICE_NAME -f
```

## ACPI Warning Mitigation

### Expected ACPI Errors (Safe to Ignore)
- TouchPad symbol resolution: `\_SB.PC00.I2C0.TPD0`
- USB-C controller: `\_SB.UBTC.RUCC`
- Impact: Cosmetic only, hardware functions normally

### When ACPI Errors Become Critical
```bash
# If ACPI errors cause hardware malfunction
# 1. Check dmesg for new error patterns
dmesg | grep -i acpi | tail -20
# 2. Verify hardware functionality
lsusb && lspci
# 3. If critical, rollback immediately
sudo nixos-rebuild switch --rollback
```

## File System Recovery

### Nix Store Issues
```bash
# Repair Nix store corruption
nix-store --verify --check-contents --repair
# Garbage collect if space issues
nix-collect-garbage -d
```

### Git Repository Recovery
```bash
# If git becomes corrupted
git fsck --full
git reflog  # Find lost commits
git reset --hard COMMIT_HASH  # Reset to known good state
```

---
*Sub-Agent A - Fix Procedures Complete*
*Executing in parallel with Prevention Guide Agent*

3. **Watchdog timeout** - System protection triggered
4. **Authentication failures** - sudo password issues

1â†’{ config, lib, pkgs, ... }:
     2â†’
     3â†’with lib;
     4â†’
     5â†’let
     6â†’  cfg = config.custom.system.hardware.monitoring;
     7â†’
     8â†’  # Hardware monitoring script for GPD Pocket 3
     9â†’  monitor-script = pkgs.writeShellScriptBin "gpd-hardware-monitor" ''
    10â†’    #!/bin/bash
    11â†’
    12â†’    # Hardware monitoring for GPD Pocket 3
    13â†’    # Monitors temperatures, fan speeds, battery, and storage health
    14â†’
    15â†’    set -euo pipefail
    16â†’
    17â†’    # Configuration
    18â†’    TEMP_HIGH_THRESHOLD=${toString cfg.alerts.temperatureHigh}
    19â†’    BATTERY_LOW_THRESHOLD=${toString cfg.alerts.batteryLow}
    20â†’    LOG_FILE="${cfg.logging.logFile}"
    21â†’    LOG_LEVEL="${cfg.logging.level}"
    22â†’    ALERT_METHOD="${cfg.alerts.method}"
    23â†’    CHECK_INTERVAL=${toString cfg.checkInterval}
    24â†’
    25â†’    # Ensure log directory exists
    26â†’    mkdir -p "$(dirname "$LOG_FILE")"
    27â†’
    28â†’    # Logging functions
    29â†’    log_message() {
    30â†’        local level="$1"
    31â†’        local message="$2"
    32â†’        local timestamp=$(${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
    33â†’
    34â†’        case "$LOG_LEVEL" in
    35â†’            "debug") echo "[$timestamp] [$level] $message" | ${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/tee -a "$LOG_FILE" ;;
    36â†’            "info")
    37â†’                if [[ "$level" != "DEBUG" ]]; then
    38â†’                    echo "[$timestamp] [$level] $message" | ${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    39â†’                fi ;;
    40â†’            "warn")
    41â†’                if [[ "$level" == "WARN" || "$level" == "ERROR" || "$level" == "CRITICAL" ]]; then
    42â†’                    echo "[$timestamp] [$level] $message" | ${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    43â†’                fi ;;
    44â†’            "error")
    45â†’                if [[ "$level" == "ERROR" || "$level" == "CRITICAL" ]]; then
    46â†’                    echo "[$timestamp] [$level] $message" | ${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    47â†’                fi ;;
    48â†’        esac
    49â†’    }
    50â†’
    51â†’    # Alert notification function
    52â†’    send_alert() {
    53â†’        local severity="$1"
    54â†’        local message="$2"
    55â†’
    56â†’        log_message "$severity" "$message"
    57â†’
    58â†’        case "$ALERT_METHOD" in
    59â†’            "notify")
    60â†’                if command -v ${pkgs.libnotify}/bin/notify-send >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    61â†’                    ${pkgs.libnotify}/bin/notify-send -u critical "Hardware Alert" "$message"
    62â†’                fi ;;
    63â†’            "systemd")
    64â†’                ${pkgs.systemd}/bin/systemd-cat -t "gpd-hardware-monitor" -p "$severity" echo "$message" ;;
    65â†’            "log")
    66â†’                # Already logged above
    67â†’                ;;
    68â†’            "all")
    69â†’                if command -v ${pkgs.libnotify}/bin/notify-send >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    70â†’                    ${pkgs.libnotify}/bin/notify-send -u critical "Hardware Alert" "$message"
    71â†’                fi
    72â†’                ${pkgs.systemd}/bin/systemd-cat -t "gpd-hardware-monitor" -p "$severity" echo "$message"
    73â†’                ;;
    74â†’        esac
    75â†’    }
    76â†’
    77â†’    # Temperature monitoring
    78â†’    check_temperatures() {
    79â†’        log_message "DEBUG" "Checking CPU/GPU temperatures"
    80â†’
    81â†’        # Initialize sensors if available
    82â†’        if command -v ${pkgs.lm_sensors}/bin/sensors-detect >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    83â†’            ${pkgs.lm_sensors}/bin/sensors >/dev/null 2>&1 || true
    84â†’        fi
    85â†’
    86â†’        # Check CPU temperature via hwmon
    87â†’        local cpu_temp=""
    88â†’        local gpu_temp=""
    89â†’
    90â†’        # Try different hwmon paths for CPU temperature
    91â†’        for hwmon in /sys/class/hwmon/hwmon*; do
    92â†’            if [[ -f "$hwmon/name" ]]; then
    93â†’                local sensor_name=$(cat "$hwmon/name")
    94â†’                case "$sensor_name" in
    95â†’                    "coretemp"|"k10temp"|"zenpower")
    96â†’                        if [[ -f "$hwmon/temp1_input" ]]; then
    97â†’                            cpu_temp=$(($(cat "$hwmon/temp1_input") / 1000))
    98â†’                            log_message "DEBUG" "CPU temperature: ''${cpu_temp}Â°C (sensor: $sensor_name)"
    99â†’                            break
   100â†’                        fi ;;
   101â†’                esac
   102â†’            fi
   103â†’        done
   104â†’
   105â†’        # Try ACPI thermal zones as fallback
   106â†’        if [[ -z "$cpu_temp" ]]; then
   107â†’            for thermal in /sys/class/thermal/thermal_zone*; do
   108â†’                if [[ -f "$thermal/temp" ]]; then
   109â†’                    local temp=$(($(cat "$thermal/temp") / 1000))
   110â†’                    if [[ $temp -gt 0 && $temp -lt 200 ]]; then  # Reasonable temperature range
   111â†’                        cpu_temp=$temp
   112â†’                        log_message "DEBUG" "CPU temperature: ''${cpu_temp}Â°C (thermal zone)"
   113â†’                        break
   114â†’                    fi
   115â†’                fi
   116â†’            done
   117â†’        fi
   118â†’
   119â†’        # Check GPU temperature (Intel integrated graphics)
   120â†’        for hwmon in /sys/class/hwmon/hwmon*; do
   121â†’            if [[ -f "$hwmon/name" ]]; then
   122â†’                local sensor_name=$(cat "$hwmon/name")
   123â†’                if [[ "$sensor_name" == "i915" ]]; then
   124â†’                    if [[ -f "$hwmon/temp1_input" ]]; then
   125â†’                        gpu_temp=$(($(cat "$hwmon/temp1_input") / 1000))
   126â†’                        log_message "DEBUG" "GPU temperature: ''${gpu_temp}Â°C"
   127â†’                        break
   128â†’                    fi
   129â†’                fi
   130â†’            fi
   131â†’        done
   132â†’
   133â†’        # Check temperature alerts
   134â†’        if [[ -n "$cpu_temp" ]] && [[ $cpu_temp -ge $TEMP_HIGH_THRESHOLD ]]; then
   135â†’            send_alert "CRITICAL" "CPU temperature critical: ''${cpu_temp}Â°C (threshold: ''${TEMP_HIGH_THRESHOLD}Â°C)"
   136â†’        fi
   137â†’
   138â†’        if [[ -n "$gpu_temp" ]] && [[ $gpu_temp -ge $TEMP_HIGH_THRESHOLD ]]; then
   139â†’            send_alert "CRITICAL" "GPU temperature critical: ''${gpu_temp}Â°C (threshold: ''${TEMP_HIGH_THRESHOLD}Â°C)"
   140â†’        fi
   141â†’
   142â†’        # Return temperatures for status display
   143â†’        echo "CPU_TEMP=$cpu_temp"
   144â†’        echo "GPU_TEMP=$gpu_temp"
   145â†’    }
   146â†’
   147â†’    # Fan speed monitoring
   148â†’    check_fan_speeds() {
   149â†’        log_message "DEBUG" "Checking fan speeds"
   150â†’
   151â†’        local fan_speed=""
   152â†’
   153â†’        # Check for fan sensors in hwmon
   154â†’        for hwmon in /sys/class/hwmon/hwmon*; do
   155â†’            if [[ -f "$hwmon/fan1_input" ]]; then
   156â†’                fan_speed=$(cat "$hwmon/fan1_input")
   157â†’                log_message "DEBUG" "Fan speed: ''${fan_speed} RPM"
   158â†’                break
   159â†’            fi
   160â†’        done
   161â†’
   162â†’        # Check ACPI fan status as fallback
   163â†’        if [[ -z "$fan_speed" ]] && [[ -d "/proc/acpi/fan" ]]; then
   164â†’            for fan_dir in /proc/acpi/fan/*/; do
   165â†’                if [[ -f "$fan_dir/state" ]]; then
   166â†’                    local fan_state=$(cat "$fan_dir/state")
   167â†’                    log_message "DEBUG" "Fan state: $fan_state"
   168â†’                fi
   169â†’            done
   170â†’        fi
   171â†’
   172â†’        echo "FAN_SPEED=$fan_speed"
   173â†’    }
   174â†’
   175â†’    # Battery health monitoring
   176â†’    check_battery() {
   177â†’        log_message "DEBUG" "Checking battery status"
   178â†’
   179â†’        local battery_level=""
   180â†’        local battery_status=""
   181â†’        local battery_health=""
   182â†’
   183â†’        # Check battery via sysfs
   184â†’        for battery in /sys/class/power_supply/BAT*; do
   185â†’            if [[ -d "$battery" ]]; then
   186â†’                if [[ -f "$battery/capacity" ]]; then
   187â†’                    battery_level=$(cat "$battery/capacity")
   188â†’                fi
   189â†’                if [[ -f "$battery/status" ]]; then
   190â†’                    battery_status=$(cat "$battery/status")
   191â†’                fi
   192â†’                if [[ -f "$battery/health" ]]; then
   193â†’                    battery_health=$(cat "$battery/health")
   194â†’                fi
   195â†’                break
   196â†’            fi
   197â†’        done
   198â†’
   199â†’        # Try ACPI as fallback
   200â†’        if [[ -z "$battery_level" ]] && command -v ${pkgs.acpi}/bin/acpi >/dev/null 2>&1; then
   201â†’            local acpi_output=$(${pkgs.acpi}/bin/acpi -b 2>/dev/null || true)
   202â†’            if [[ -n "$acpi_output" ]]; then
   203â†’                battery_level=$(echo "$acpi_output" | ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -oP '\d+(?=%)' | head -1)
   204â†’                battery_status=$(echo "$acpi_output" | ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -oP '(Charging|Discharging|Full|Unknown)' | head -1)
   205â†’            fi
   206â†’        fi
   207â†’
   208â†’        log_message "DEBUG" "Battery: ''${battery_level}% (''${battery_status}) Health: ''${battery_health}"
   209â†’
   210â†’        # Check battery alerts
   211â†’        if [[ -n "$battery_level" ]] && [[ $battery_level -le $BATTERY_LOW_THRESHOLD ]] && [[ "$battery_status" == "Discharging" ]]; then
   212â†’            send_alert "WARN" "Battery level low: ''${battery_level}% (threshold: ''${BATTERY_LOW_THRESHOLD}%)"
   213â†’        fi
   214â†’
   215â†’        echo "BATTERY_LEVEL=$battery_level"
   216â†’        echo "BATTERY_STATUS=$battery_status"
   217â†’        echo "BATTERY_HEALTH=$battery_health"
   218â†’    }
   219â†’
   220â†’    # Storage health monitoring
   221â†’    check_storage() {
   222â†’        log_message "DEBUG" "Checking storage health"
   223â†’
   224â†’        # Get all block devices
   225â†’        for device in $(${pkgs.util-linux}/bin/lsblk -dno NAME | ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -E '^(sd|nvme|mmc)'); do
   226â†’            local device_path="/dev/$device"
   227â†’
   228â†’            # Skip if device doesn't exist
   229â†’            [[ -b "$device_path" ]] || continue
   230â†’
   231â†’            log_message "DEBUG" "Checking storage device: $device_path"
   232â†’
   233â†’            # Check SMART status if available
   234â†’            if command -v ${pkgs.smartmontools}/bin/smartctl >/dev/null 2>&1; then
   235â†’                local smart_output=$(${pkgs.smartmontools}/bin/smartctl -H "$device_path" 2>/dev/null || true)
   236â†’                if [[ -n "$smart_output" ]]; then
   237â†’                    if echo "$smart_output" | ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -q "PASSED"; then
   238â†’                        log_message "DEBUG" "SMART status for $device: PASSED"
   239â†’                    elif echo "$smart_output" | ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -q "FAILED"; then
   240â†’                        send_alert "CRITICAL" "SMART status for $device: FAILED"
   241â†’                    fi
   242â†’                fi
   243â†’
   244â†’                # Check temperature for NVMe drives
   245â†’                if [[ "$device" =~ ^nvme ]]; then
   246â†’                    local nvme_temp=$(${pkgs.smartmontools}/bin/smartctl -a "$device_path" 2>/dev/null | \
   247â†’                        ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -oP 'Temperature:\s+\K\d+' || echo "")
   248â†’                    if [[ -n "$nvme_temp" ]]; then
   249â†’                        log_message "DEBUG" "NVMe temperature for $device: ''${nvme_temp}Â°C"
   250â†’                        if [[ $nvme_temp -ge 70 ]]; then  # NVMe thermal throttling threshold
   251â†’                            send_alert "WARN" "NVMe temperature high for $device: ''${nvme_temp}Â°C"
   252â†’                        fi
   253â†’                    fi
   254â†’                fi
   255â†’            fi
   256â†’        done
   257â†’    }
   258â†’
   259â†’    # Main monitoring loop
   260â†’    run_monitoring() {
   261â†’        log_message "INFO" "Starting hardware monitoring for GPD Pocket 3"
   262â†’
   263â†’        while true; do
   264â†’            {
   265â†’                check_temperatures
   266â†’                check_fan_speeds
   267â†’                check_battery
   268â†’                check_storage
   269â†’                echo "LAST_CHECK=$(${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')"
   270â†’            } > /tmp/gpd-hardware-status
   271â†’
   272â†’            ${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/sleep "$CHECK_INTERVAL"
   273â†’        done
   274â†’    }
   275â†’
   276â†’    # Handle script arguments
   277â†’    case "''${1:-monitor}" in
   278â†’        "monitor")
   279â†’            run_monitoring ;;
   280â†’        "status")
   281â†’            if [[ -f /tmp/gpd-hardware-status ]]; then
   282â†’                cat /tmp/gpd-hardware-status
   283â†’            else
   284â†’                echo "No monitoring data available"
   285â†’                exit 1
   286â†’            fi ;;
   287â†’        "test")
   288â†’            log_message "INFO" "Running hardware monitoring test"
   289â†’            check_temperatures
   290â†’            check_fan_speeds
   291â†’            check_battery
   292â†’            check_storage
   293â†’            log_message "INFO" "Hardware monitoring test completed" ;;
   294â†’        *)
   295â†’            echo "Usage: $0 {monitor|status|test}"
   296â†’            echo "  monitor - Start continuous monitoring (default)"
   297â†’            echo "  status  - Show current hardware status"
   298â†’            echo "  test    - Run one-time hardware check"
   299â†’            exit 1 ;;
   300â†’    esac
   301â†’  '';
   302â†’
   303â†’  # Status display script
   304â†’  status-script = pkgs.writeShellScriptBin "gpd-hardware-status" ''
   305â†’    #!/bin/bash
   306â†’
   307â†’    # Display hardware status in human-readable format
   308â†’
   309â†’    if [[ ! -f /tmp/gpd-hardware-status ]]; then
   310â†’        echo "Hardware monitoring not running or no data available"
   311â†’        echo "Start monitoring with: systemctl --user start gpd-hardware-monitor"
   312â†’        exit 1
   313â†’    fi
   314â†’
   315â†’    source /tmp/gpd-hardware-status
   316â†’
   317â†’    echo "=== GPD Pocket 3 Hardware Status ==="
   318â†’    echo "Last Check: $LAST_CHECK"
   319â†’    echo ""
   320â†’
   321â†’    echo "Temperatures:"
   322â†’    if [[ -n "$CPU_TEMP" ]]; then
   323â†’        echo "  CPU: ''${CPU_TEMP}Â°C"
   324â†’    else
   325â†’        echo "  CPU: Not available"
   326â†’    fi
   327â†’
   328â†’    if [[ -n "$GPU_TEMP" ]]; then
   329â†’        echo "  GPU: ''${GPU_TEMP}Â°C"
   330â†’    else
   331â†’        echo "  GPU: Not available"
   332â†’    fi
   333â†’    echo ""
   334â†’
   335â†’    echo "Fan:"
   336â†’    if [[ -n "$FAN_SPEED" ]]; then
   337â†’        echo "  Speed: ''${FAN_SPEED} RPM"
   338â†’    else
   339â†’        echo "  Speed: Not available"
   340â†’    fi
   341â†’    echo ""
   342â†’
   343â†’    echo "Battery:"
   344â†’    if [[ -n "$BATTERY_LEVEL" ]]; then
   345â†’        echo "  Level: ''${BATTERY_LEVEL}%"
   346â†’        echo "  Status: ''${BATTERY_STATUS:-Unknown}"
   347â†’        if [[ -n "$BATTERY_HEALTH" ]]; then
   348â†’            echo "  Health: $BATTERY_HEALTH"
   349â†’        fi
   350â†’    else
   351â†’        echo "  Status: Not available"
   352â†’    fi
   353â†’    echo ""
   354â†’
   355â†’    echo "Alerts:"
   356â†’    local alert_count=$(${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -c "WARN\|CRITICAL" "${cfg.logging.logFile}" 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
   357â†’    echo "  Recent alerts: $alert_count (check ${cfg.logging.logFile})"
   358â†’  '';

   360â†’in {
   361â†’  options.custom.system.hardware.monitoring = {
   362â†’    enable = mkEnableOption "GPD Pocket 3 hardware monitoring";
   363â†’
   364â†’    checkInterval = mkOption {
   365â†’      type = types.int;

   376â†’
   377â†’      batteryLow = mkOption {

   381â†’      };
   382â†’
   383â†’      method = mkOption {

   389â†’
   390â†’    logging = {

   406â†’        description = "Logging level";

   410â†’
   411â†’  config = mkIf cfg.enable {
   412â†’    # Required packages
   413â†’    environment.systemPackages = with pkgs; [
   414â†’      lm_sensors
   415â†’      smartmontools

   422â†’    # Enable hardware sensors
   423â†’    hardware.sensor.iio.enable = true;
   424â†’
   425â†’    # Kernel modules for sensors
   426â†’    boot.kernelModules = [ "coretemp" "i915" ];
   427â†’
   428â†’    # Initialize lm-sensors
   429â†’    environment.etc."sensors.conf" = {

   432â†’
   433â†’        chip "coretemp-*"

   435â†’
   436â†’        chip "i915-*"
   437â†’          label temp1 "GPU Temperature"
   438â†’      '';
   439â†’    };
   440â†’
   441â†’    # User systemd service for hardware monitoring
   442â†’    systemd.user.services.gpd-hardware-monitor = {
   443â†’      description = "GPD Pocket 3 Hardware Monitor";
   444â†’      wantedBy = [ "default.target" ];
   445â†’      after = [ "graphical-session.target" ];
   446â†’
   447â†’      serviceConfig = {

   450â†’        ExecReload = "${pkgs.coreutils}/bin/kill -HUP $MAINPID";
   451â†’        Restart = "always";

   453â†’
   454â†’        # Security settings
   455â†’        NoNewPrivileges = true;

   459â†’        ReadWritePaths = [

   462â†’        ];
   463â†’
   464â†’        # Resource limits

   467â†’      };
   468â†’
   469â†’      environment = {

   471â†’      };
   472â†’    };
   473â†’
   474â†’    # System timer for periodic health checks
   475â†’    systemd.timers.gpd-hardware-health-check = mkIf cfg.logging.enable {
   476â†’      description = "GPD Pocket 3 Hardware Health Check Timer";
   477â†’      wantedBy = [ "timers.target" ];
   478â†’
   479â†’      timerConfig = {
   480â†’        OnBootSec = "5m";
   481â†’        OnUnitActiveSec = "1h";
   482â†’        Unit = "gpd-hardware-health-check.service";
   483â†’      };
   484â†’    };
   485â†’
   486â†’    systemd.services.gpd-hardware-health-check = mkIf cfg.logging.enable {
   487â†’      description = "GPD Pocket 3 Hardware Health Check";
   488â†’
   489â†’      serviceConfig = {
   490â†’        Type = "oneshot";
   491â†’        ExecStart = "${monitor-script}/bin/gpd-hardware-monitor test";
   492â†’        User = "root";
   493â†’
   494â†’        # Security settings
   495â†’        NoNewPrivileges = true;
   496â†’        PrivateTmp = true;
   497â†’        ProtectSystem = "strict";
   498â†’        ReadWritePaths = [
   499â†’          "/tmp"
   500â†’          (dirOf cfg.logging.logFile)
   501â†’        ];
   502â†’      };
   503â†’
   504â†’      environment = {
   505â†’        PATH = mkDefault "/run/current-system/sw/bin";
   506â†’      };
   507â†’    };
   508â†’
   509â†’    # Log rotation
   510â†’    services.logrotate.settings."${cfg.logging.logFile}" = mkIf cfg.logging.enable {
   511â†’      frequency = "weekly";
   512â†’      rotate = 4;
   513â†’      compress = true;
   514â†’      delaycompress = true;
   515â†’      missingok = true;
   516â†’      notifempty = true;
   517â†’      create = "644 root root";
   518â†’      postrotate = ''
   519â†’        systemctl reload gpd-hardware-monitor || true
   520â†’      '';
   521â†’    };
   522â†’
   523â†’    # Create log directory
   524â†’    systemd.tmpfiles.rules = mkIf cfg.logging.enable [
   525â†’      "d ${dirOf cfg.logging.logFile} 0755 root root -"
   526â†’      "f ${cfg.logging.logFile} 0644 root root -"
   527â†’    ];
   528â†’
   529â†’    # Shell aliases for convenience
   530â†’    environment.shellAliases = {

   532â†’      hwmon-log = "tail -f ${cfg.logging.logFile}";
   533â†’      hwmon-test = "${monitor-script}/bin/gpd-hardware-monitor test";
   534â†’    };
   535â†’  };
   536â†’}
